canonical_intents.definition: Identify and highlight weaknesses in the methodology used in the research.
canonical_intents.name: Expose_Methodological_Weakness

canonical_intents.definition: Address and correct any misunderstandings regarding the research or its findings.
canonical_intents.name: Clarify_Misunderstanding

canonical_intents.definition: Argue for the uniqueness and significance of the research compared to previous studies.
canonical_intents.name: Defend_Novelty_Against_Prior_Work

canonical_intents.definition: Provide a theoretical basis or justification for the research approach or findings.
canonical_intents.name: Establish_Theoretical_Grounding

canonical_intents.definition: Acknowledge minor criticisms while maintaining the overall strength of the main argument.
canonical_intents.name: Concede_Minor_Point_To_Win_Major

canonical_intents.definition: Redirect the responsibility of providing evidence or justification to the opposing side.
canonical_intents.name: Shift_Burden_Of_Proof

canonical_intents.definition: Justify the chosen methods and approaches used in the research.
canonical_intents.name: Defend_Methodological_Choice

canonical_intents.definition: Show that the authors have addressed reviewer comments and made necessary revisions.
canonical_intents.name: Demonstrate_Responsiveness

canonical_intents.definition: Ask for a more thorough examination or investigation of specific aspects of the research.
canonical_intents.name: Request_Deeper_Analysis

canonical_intents.definition: Respond to feedback regarding the clarity and presentation of the research.
canonical_intents.name: Address_Presentation_Feedback

canonical_intents.definition: Question the originality or significance of the research contributions.
canonical_intents.name: Challenge_Novelty

canonical_intents.definition: Provide detailed explanations of the experimental design and setup used in the research.
canonical_intents.name: Clarify_Experimental_Setup

items.rationale: Identifying weaknesses in methodology is a key aspect of peer review.
Addressing misunderstandings is crucial for clear communication of research findings.
Establishing the novelty of research is essential in academic discourse.
Providing theoretical justification is important for validating research claims.
Acknowledging minor points can strengthen the overall argument.
Redirecting the burden of proof is a common rhetorical strategy in debates.
Justifying methodological choices is critical in defending research integrity.
Showing responsiveness to feedback is important for maintaining credibility.
Asking for deeper analysis can lead to more robust findings.
Responding to presentation feedback improves the clarity of the research.
Questioning novelty is a critical part of evaluating research contributions.
Providing clarity on experimental setup is essential for reproducibility.
